title: Former Whyalla steelworks owner owed $18.5 million in royalties | ABC NEWS
description: The former owner of the Whyalla steelworks owed the South Australian government $18.5 million in royalties before administrators took over. Internal documents obtained under FOI laws detail the company's history of delayed payments in the lead-up to the intervention. Administrators are looking for a new owner for the steelworks, with the process expected to be finalised later this year. title: Oil stocks tumble as Trump walks back Iran strike threats | Finance Report | ABC NEWS
description: Santos, Woodside and energy stocks fell sharply, along with the price of crude oil after Donald Trump toned down his language on whether the United States would launch a strike against Iran.  Meanwhile, the world's largest manufacturer of artificial intelligence (AI) chips, TSMC, reported a surge in quarterly profit, which boosted Wall Street and the ASX, as finance presenter David Chau explains. title: Fmr South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol sentenced over martial law declaration | ABC NEWS
description: Yoon Suk Yeol has been sentenced to five years in jail over his failed attempt at imposing martial law in South Korea. The former president's declaration of martial law in late 2024 plunged South Korea into political turmoil and led to his impeachment. description: The United States has traded strikes for sanctions in the wake of Iran's deadly crackdown on anti-government protesters. An emergency meeting has been held at the UN Security Council to discuss the crisis as concerns grow that the death toll could be much higher than previously thought. title: Lorne locals clean up after cars, caravans swept out to sea | ABC NEWS
description: Clean-up efforts along Victoria's Great Ocean Road have started after severe flash flooding caused significant damage. Up to 300 people were displaced, with 60 seeking shelter in relief centres. No one is reported missing or seriously injured, but several vehicles are still submerged in the ocean. title: Can Nobel Peace Prize be transferred to President Trump? | ABC NEWS
description: Venezuela's opposition leader María Corina Machado says she has presented her Nobel Peace Prize to US President Donald Trump. The Norwegian Nobel Institute has said the prize cannot be transferred, shared or revoked and that the decision to award a Nobel Prize is final and permanent.  Reporting by Amal Wehbe, ABC News Social Media team.  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Council considers options for Bondi bridge and permanent memorial | ABC NEWS
description: Waverley Council plans to create memorials for the victims of the Bondi terror attack and to honour those who showed bravery. No decision has been made about the future of the footbridge used in the attack, which killed 15 people. Still, many support keeping it rather than demolishing it. title: Former South Korean president Yoon Suk Yeol sentenced to jail | ABC NEWS
description: Seoul Central District Court ruled Yoon had resisted arrest for weeks after his impeachment by barricading himself inside the presidential compound.   The 65-year-old was also found guilty of failing to consult a legally required full cabinet meeting before announcing martial law, and ordering evidence be deleted from phones.   Friday’s sentencing is the first resolution of four trials related to the martial law declaration.  The most serious charge of launching an insurrection will be ruled on in February and prosecutors have revealed they’ll be seeking the death penalty.  Yoon has always denied the allegations. title: Apology to author locks in Adelaide Festival headliner, Pulp | ABC NEWS
description: British indie band Pulp will honour its scheduled performance at the Adelaide Festival next month after organisers apologised to Australian-Palestinian author Randa Abdel-Fattah.  The band was among the acts prepared to boycott the event after the author's slot at Writers' Week was cancelled over her commentary on Israel and Zionism.  The band says it had previously informed festival organisers of its decision to withdraw but was asked "to delay an announcement while they sought to resolve this crisis for all sides". title: Hundreds gather outside Sydney Town Hall to oppose NSW protest laws | ABC NEWS
description: A man has been arrested at a pro-Palestinian rally outside Sydney Town Hall. Rally organisers say the demonstration is in opposition of new state laws preventing some public assemblies, introduced in response to the Bondi terror attack. Activists fear the new laws will impede upcoming Invasion Day protests. title: Religious leaders write to PM with concerns over hate speech bill | ABC NEWS
description: Religious leaders have raised concerns over the government's proposed hate speech laws, warning about potential threats to religious freedoms.  The bill has failed to secure enough support as an emergency session of parliament approaches. Anthony Albanese urged the opposition to collaborate on the new laws after Sussan Ley deemed the draft bill "virtually unsalvageable," the opposition leader saying it neglects antisemitism and could limit free speech. title: Female athletes share struggles with body image and disordered eating | ABC NEWS
description: Matilda Friend was once one of Australia's top figure skaters, but as her career flourished she harboured body image issues and struggled with disordered eating. An ABC survey of women in sports found she's not alone — 27% of respondents also had negative feelings about their body image. It's a familiar story for former rugby union player Melanie Kawa, who dealt with disordered eating for most of her career.
